title: 103_hr4711
content: Title I of the United States Code, known as the "Spousal Equity in Bankruptcy Amendments of 1994," includes amendments to Title 11. The short title for this section is "Spousal Equity in Bankruptcy Amendments of 1994." The "Spousal Equity in Bankruptcy Amendments of 1994" amends Section 362(b)(2) of title 11, United States Code, regarding relief from automatic stay for actions related to paternity, alimony, maintenance, or support. It also amends Section 507 of title 11, United States Code, to adjust the priority of claims. The "Spousal Equity in Bankruptcy Amendments of 1994" modifies Section 507 of title 11, United States Code, to include unsecured claims for alimony, maintenance, or support of a spouse or child in certain circumstances. The amendments to Title 11 of the United States Code in 1994 included changes to Section 507, expanding the definition of debts to include liabilities designated as alimony, maintenance, or support under certain conditions. The amendments to Title 11 of the United States Code in 1994 included changes to Section 507, expanding the definition of debts to include liabilities designated as alimony, maintenance, or support under certain conditions. Additionally, various sections were amended to include specific references to sections 507(a)(6), 507(a)(7), and 507(a)(8) in relation to judicial liens and protection of liens. The amendments to Title 11 of the United States Code in 1994 expanded the definition of debts to include liabilities designated as alimony, maintenance, or support under certain conditions. This includes a liability designated as alimony, maintenance, or support, unless such liability is actually in the nature of alimony, maintenance, or support. The 1994 amendments to Title 11 of the United States Code expanded the definition of debts to include liabilities related to divorce or separation, unless discharging such debt would result in a benefit to the debtor that outweighs the detrimental consequences to a spouse, former spouse, or child of the debtor. The 1994 amendments to Title 11 of the United States Code expanded the definition of debts to include liabilities related to divorce or separation. Section 547(c) of title 11 is amended to provide protection against trustee avoidance for bona fide payments of debt to a spouse, former spouse, or child of the debtor for alimony, maintenance, or support in connection with a separation agreement, divorce decree, or other court order. Child support creditors or their representatives can intervene in bankruptcy proceedings without charge or meeting special court rules if they file a detailed statement about the child support debt. The National Bankruptcy Review Commission, also known as the Commission, is established under the National Bankruptcy Review Commission Act. Its duties include reviewing bankruptcy laws and making recommendations. The National Bankruptcy Review Commission, or the Commission, is tasked with investigating issues related to the Bankruptcy Code, evaluating proposals, submitting reports to Congress, Chief Justice, and the President, gathering diverse opinions on the bankruptcy system, and studying the impact of bankruptcy laws on families, especially women and children living in poverty after divorce. The National Bankruptcy Review Commission consists of 10 members with expertise in bankruptcy law appointed by various officials. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and a quorum is six members. The National Bankruptcy Review Commission consists of 10 members with expertise in bankruptcy law appointed by various officials. A quorum is required for meetings, but a lesser number can conduct them. Appointments must be made within 60 days of enactment, with the first meeting held within 90 days. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members appointed as government officials can continue for up to 90 days if they leave office. The Commission members can serve for up to 90 days after leaving office. Prior to appointments, officials must consult to ensure diverse representation in the Commission and its staff. SEC. 205 of the text outlines the compensation for Commission members, with non-government employees receiving daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, and government employees serving without additional compensation. Members are also reimbursed for travel expenses. SEC. 206 discusses the staff of the Commission, including experts and consultants. The chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint and terminate an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The chairman can also determine their compensation, not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can hire experts and consultants temporarily under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 207. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal departments, and receive support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission has the authority to utilize facilities, support services, and the United States mails as needed. Expenditures and contracts can be made for necessary supplies and services within the limits set by appropriation Acts. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts or donations of services or property. The Commission established in the legislation must submit a report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations to Congress, the Chief Justice, and the President within 2 years of its first meeting. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $1,500,000 is authorized for carrying out the provisions of this title.
